items.title: Rubio reiterates unwavering US support for Israel as dozens killed in Gaza City offensive
items.summary: The US secretary of state said Israel's recent airstrike in Qatar was "not going to change the nature of our relationship with the Israelis" but the two nations were "going to have to talk about" its impact on Gaza ceasefire negotiations.

items.title: This common bathroom habit could be doing you more damage than you think
items.summary: Using your phone on the throne could lead to an increased risk of haemorrhoids, according to a new study, but some experts say it's not the full story.

items.title: Australia announces more defence funding| Evening News Bulletin 14 September 2025
items.summary: Australia's AUKUS partners will benefit from a $12 billion boost to defence spending; nine people charged in raids targeting online child abuse; and Australian sprinter Torrie Lewis through to the 100m semi final at the World Athletics Championships.

items.title: Romania scrambles fighter jets in response to Russian drones | Midday News Bulletin 14 September 2025
items.summary: The government announces $1.2 billion in defence spending linked to the AUKUS agreement; Romania scrambles fighter jets in response to Russian drones; and in sport, the Lions book their spot in the AFL preliminary finals.

items.title: Government to spend $12 billion on 'world-class' AUKUS defence facility in WA
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a $12 billion investment into a Western Australian defence precinct, which is set to bolster Australia's ability to build warships and host nuclear-powered submarines.

items.title: Torrie Lewis breaks her own Australian 100m record at World Athletics Championships 2025
items.summary: Sprint queen Torrie Lewis has given Australia a flying start to the world athletics championships with a record-breaking 100m run.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Is there life on Mars? New research seems to show there was, once.
items.summary: This week, NASA announced findings of potential biosignatures on Mars. Does that mean there's proof that there was once life on Mars? In this edition of Weekend One on One, Dr Micheal Tice, geology professor at Texas A&M University, who's involved in the ongoing research project, explains what the findings mean.

items.title: INTERVIEW: The new Aged Care Act and the 'unintended consequences' preventing transformational change
items.summary: A new Aged Care Act is weeks away from coming into effect, but there are aspects that has the Inspector-General of Aged Care concerned.

items.title: Competing protests in Australia's major cities | Morning News Bulletin 14 September 2025
items.summary: Police intervene to stop protesters clashing in Melbourne; a vigil held for slain conservative activist Charlie Kirk; and in sport, Alex de Minaur crashes out of the Davis Cup in Sydney.

items.title: Loo scrolling: Study investigates link between this bathroom habit and a painful health condition
items.summary: Using your phone while on the toilet could be linked to an increased chance of haemorrhoids, according to a study from the United States. So if you're a loo scroller, the extra time spent on the toilet could be doing you more harm than good.

items.title: What next for the Coalition after its 'entirely unedifying week'?
items.summary: Liberal senator Jane Hume says the Coalition is looking to "move on" after demoting colleague Jacinta Nampijinpa Price over controversial comments about Indian immigration. But what are the lessons the Coalition should draw from the episode?

items.title: 'I'm ready to be arrested': How women in Iran fight 'state-sanctioned sexual violence'
items.summary: Three years after the death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini, which sparked the widespread "Woman, Life, Freedom" movement, women are still finding ways to protest against the regime's new methods of crackdown.

items.title: Nick was a 'subservient' child in church, but 'tiny little cracks' eventually shattered his faith
items.summary: It took an "unravelling" for musician Nick Carpenter to be able to reckon with his religious upbringing in America's south and find his voice in songwriting. But he still thinks about the person he could have been.

items.title: Concerns over political extremism after rival rallies held across Australia
items.summary: Politicians are warning against the risks of extremism and political violence, after rival rallies were held in Australia's capital cities and regional centres.

items.title: Protesters clash in Melbourne as rival rallies unfold across the country
items.summary: Opposing protests took place across all capital cities and some regional areas on Saturday and, as police had predicted, things got most heated in Melbourne

items.title: Evening News Bulletin 13 September 2025
items.summary: Police deployed to separate rival protests in Australia's capital cities and regional centres; the widow of conservative political activist Charlie Kirk speaks out; and in sport, Australian Jai Hindley closing in on a podium finish at the Vuelta a Espana.

items.title: Muslim leaders call for more government action to mend 'severely fractured relationship'
items.summary: Prominent Muslims have called on the Australian government to mend its "fractured" relationship with their community, as Anthony Albanese says he will "carefully consider" the special envoy to combat Islamophobia's recommendations.

items.title: Muslim leaders call for more government action to mend 'severely fractured relationship'
items.summary: Prominent Muslims have called on the Australian government to mend its "fractured" relationship with their community, as Anthony Albanese says he will "carefully consider" the special envoy to combat Islamophobia's recommendations.

items.title: Nepal announces interim leader, sets election date after week of violent protests
items.summary: Sushila Karki has become Nepal's first woman prime minister, following two days of intense negotiations between the president, army chief and protest leaders behind the country's worst upheaval in years, which left at least 51 people dead.

items.title: 'We got him': Authorities arrest a suspect in fatal shooting of Charlie Kirk
items.summary: A 22-year-old man has been arrested over the shooting death of Charlie Kirk at a Utah University. He's been identified as Tyler Robinson, a Utah resident who family members say had recently become more 'political' and increasingly vocal in his opposition to the conservative activist's ideas.

items.title: Police in Australia raise concerns ahead of protests | Afternoon Bulletin 13 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Police are concerned about chaos, as left and right wing protests begin; Social media platforms urged to take down videos of the Charlie Kirk shooting; and in sport; Officials found to have placed hundreds of bets on races in Tasmania.

items.title: Neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell given community work order for intimidating police officer
items.summary: Thomas Sewell was found guilty of intimidating a police officer over threats to "dox" him and his wife.

items.title: 'Paradigm shift': Over 2 million homes to get internet speed boost starting this weekend
items.summary: The free speed boost is one of the biggest changes to Australian internet in history, according to one expert.

items.title: PM's wardrobe malfunction and SUV diplomacy: What you missed from the Pacific summit
items.summary: Australia's fossil fuel exports remain a source of tension as Pacific leaders double down on their support for a bid to co-host global climate talks.

items.title: 'More political in recent years': Fresh details emerge about suspected Charlie Kirk shooter
items.summary: Tyler Robinson expressed dislike for Charlie Kirk in the lead-up to the conservative commentator's assassination, investigators have been told.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Supermarket sweep: How making wise choices could save you money
items.summary: Making the switch from branded products to a store's home brand alternatives could save shoppers thousands of dollars each year at checkout, according to a financial comparison website. SBS's Cameron Carr has been finding out more from Compare the Market spokesman Phillip Portman.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Three years after the death of Mahsa Amini in Iran, what's changed?
items.summary: Dr Dara Conduit at the University of Melbourne explains the impact of the death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini three years ago on women's rights in Iran today.

items.title: A suspect arrested in the shooting of Charlie Kirk | Morning Bulletin 13 September
items.summary: In this bulletin, A suspect arrested in the shooting of Charlie Kirk as local supporters hold a vigil; Australia's Muslim community welcomes a report into Islamophobia; and in sport, Australian basketball star Tiana Mangakahia dies of cancer at the age of 30.

items.title: Bruce McAvaney on Australia's emerging athletics 'golden age' and the run that inspired us all
items.summary: Australia's "golden age" in athletics is gathering steam, esteemed sports commentator Bruce McAvaney says, as the World Athletics Championships gets underway.

items.title: $548.5 million: The price the government is willing to pay 'to avoid a public trial' of robodebt
items.summary: The robodebt class action settlement has been billed as the largest of its kind in Australian history. However, one expert argues it represents "accountability avoided", leaving questions of misfeasance unanswered.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Envoy Aftab Malik on 'going to the roots' of Islamophobia in Australia
items.summary: The Special Envoy to Combat Islamophobia has handed down his long-awaited report, containing 54 recommendations to the federal government.

items.title: Former Virgin CEO’s $50m payday; & is a US rate cut locked in?
items.summary: Former Virgin Australia CEO Jayne Hrdlicka is collecting a $49.9 million pay packet, which includes 10 million shares, as revealed in the company’s annual report. For more on this and the ASX-200’s performance this week, Stephanie Youssef spoke with IG Markets analyst Tony Sycamore. Plus, US inflation has risen 2.9% in August, paving the way for the first US interest rate cut of the year when the Federal Reserve meets next week. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with AMP Chief Economist Shane Oliver.

items.title: Why the final approval for North West Shelf gas plant has Indigenous groups and environmentalists worried
items.summary: The federal government has given the final approval for the Woodside North West Shelf gas project with a series of conditions. The approval comes ahead of the Albanese government's announcement of a 2035 emissions reduction target, and after Australia emphasised its commitment to tackling climate change to Pacific leaders.

items.title: "Terrifying reality" Islamophobia envoy calls for urgent action | Evening News Bulletin
items.summary: In this bulletin, the Federal Government is handed dozens of recommendations to combat Islamophobia, the environment minister says final approval of the extension of a gas project is subject to conditions. And in tennis, Australia eyes a top 8 qualifying spot in the Davis Cup, playing Belgium this weekend.

items.title: 'Terrifying reality': Islamophobia report handed down as envoy calls for 'urgent' action
items.summary: The special envoy to combat Islamophobia has released his report, finding Islamophobia is "pervasive" in Australia and has "skyrocketed" since the Hamas-Israel war erupted.

items.title: Federal government approves Woodside gas project extension, with some conditions
items.summary: The country's largest gas project's potential operating life has been extended to 2070.

items.title: A 5-minute guide to the World Athletics Championships – and how to watch from Australia
items.summary: Australia has kicked off one of its biggest track and field campaigns in history, with a record number of athletes in Tokyo to contest the 2025 World Athletics Championships.

items.title: Charlie Kirk shooting: More clues as search for shooter intensifies
items.summary: The hunt for the killer of conservative activist Charlie Kirk continues, with US federal investigators pursuing new leads in Utah. The FBI has released images of the suspect and is offering a reward of up to A$150,000 (US$$100,000) for information.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 12 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Brazil's former President Bolsonaro sentenced to jail
items.summary: Brazil's former President, Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to prison after being convicted of plotting a coup to remain in power after losing the 2022 election. Mr Bolsonaro, who has denied any wrongdoing, has not attended the court and has only sent his lawyers.He is the first former president in the country's history to be convicted for attacking democracy.

items.title: Former Brazilian President jailed for 27 years | Midday News Bulletin 12 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Anthony Albanese is thankful for Pacific leaders support on Australia’s bid to host climate talks, a former Brazilian President is jailed for decades over an attempted election coup. And in sport, Greg Norman bows out of the LIV golf tour.

items.title: What we know about the Charlie Kirk shooting suspect
items.summary: More photos have been released of a "person of interest" in relation to the shooting of right-wing activist Charlie Kirk. There is still no suspect in custody.

items.title: Ireland says it will boycott Eurovision 2026 if Israel is allowed to participate
items.summary: Irish broadcaster RTE said it would be "unconscionable" to take part in the contest alongside Israel, given its ongoing assault on Gaza.

items.title: 'Doesn't cut the mustard': Indian Australian community leaders demand Price apology
items.summary: While welcoming an apology from Opposition leader Sussan Ley, one Indian Australian community figure said "the Liberal Party has their work cut out to repair the damage" caused by senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's comments on Indian immigration.

items.title: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years in jail for plotting coup
items.summary: The firebrand ex-president was convicted of plotting a coup after his 2022 election loss, and accused of acting "with the purpose of eroding democracy and institutions".

items.title: MORNING NEWS BULLETIN 12 SEPTEMBER 2025
items.summary: US authorities search for the gunman that allegedly killed Charlie Kirk; Two Victorian Police officers charged with negligent manslaughter; Former St Kilda star Nicky Winmar appears in court on a charge of domestic violence.

items.title: Anthony Albanese says shooting of Charlie Kirk 'horrific' and world is 'shocked'
items.summary: Other Australian politicians have also reacted to the fatal shooting of the American right-wing commentator. It comes as investigators in the US said they are searching for a "college-aged" person.

items.title: More than a million Australians could be living with dementia in 40 years. These are possible risk factors
items.summary: A new report has also found dementia was Australia's leading cause of death in 2023.

items.title: 'People starting to act out': How the Charlie Kirk shooting suggests a 'vicious spiral' in the US
items.summary: Is the US seeing a rise in political violence, and could it spread to Australia?

items.title: Julie Bishop hits back at bullying claims and vows to stay at ANU after deputy quits
items.summary: ANU chancellor Julie Bishop has rejected bullying allegations, and has vowed to serve out her term after vice-chancellor Genevieve Bell quit following months of controversy.

items.title: Sydney sets 146-year rainfall record as severe weather eases
items.summary: Over the 24 hours to 9am on Thursday, Sydney received a total of 122mm of rain, marking its heaviest daily rainfall for September since 1879.

items.title: US stocks benefit from Oracle surge; home ownership dream slipping
items.summary: The ASX 200 has closed 0.3% lower with healthcare stocks dragging the index down, despite gains by gold miners. That’s almost despite Oracle’s shares soaring almost 40% in its best one-day performance since 1992, lifting the S&P 500 and other global markets to record highs. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Mark Gardner from MPC Markets. Plus, new analysis from Domain shows the dream of owning a home is becoming further out of reach – with deposit hurdles, coupled with climbing house prices and mortgage repayments, driving the sharpest generational divide in decades. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Domain’s research chief, Dr Nicola Powell.

items.title: What you might not know about tornadoes in Australia
items.summary: There are about 60-80 tornadoes each year in Australia, according to a meteorologist. But you're unlikely to see them.

items.title: Israel strikes Qatar, why it's been a bad week to be a PM & the real 'Succession' finale
items.summary: Israel's strike on Qatar blows up ceasefire talks, the prime ministers of Nepal, Japan and France depart in a hurry, and Albanese battles for influence in the Pacific, while Moldova battles to stop Putin’s influence ahead of elections. Plus, the Murdoch succession is finally settled.

items.title: Charlie Kirk 'a man of deep faith' says Trump | Evening News Bulletin 11 September 2025
items.summary: Donald Trump condemns the shooting of conservative influencer Charlie Kirk; Australia signs on to the Pacific Resilience Facility as it moves to bolster ties in the region; and in sport, "devastated" paddling champion Jess Fox will not compete at the Slalom World Championships.

items.title: 'I won't be silenced': Jacinta Price axed from Coalition frontbench in fallout over Indian migration remarks
items.summary: Northern Territory Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price has been removed from the Coalition frontbench, following fallout from remarks she made about Indian migrants. Sydney Lang takes a look at how the last week unfolded.

items.title: Australians on Gaza flotilla say they remain 'steadfast' after alleged drone attacks
items.summary: There are believed to be about 10 Australians involved in the Global Sumud Flotilla, which is attempting to break Israel's naval blockade of Gaza.

items.title: Europe on high alert after Russian drones shot down over Poland
items.summary: Poland has reported its most serious airspace breach since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, after nearly 20 drones entered from Belarus and Ukraine. European leaders have condemned Moscow for reckless escalation, with the Kremlin saying such accusations are baseless.

items.title: Rare double tornado seen in New South Wales | Midday News Bulletin 11 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, a rare double tornado phenomenon in New South Wales, Sussan Ley apologises to Indian Australian community, for comments by ousted frontbencher. And in tennis, Lleyton Hewitt to captain Australia in this weekend's Davis Cup match, after an improper conduct fine.

items.title: Ley apologises to Indian Australians, says Price remains 'valued' party member after sacking
items.summary: Sussan Ley's apology come after she dumped Jacinta Nampijinpa Price from the Opposition frontbench over the senator's remarks about Indian migrants and her refusal to endorse her leadership.

items.summary: Ever wondered what "girt by sea" means, especially if your first language isn't English? SBS Audio has brought Australia’s national anthem to life in more than 60 languages, so everyone can understand the words behind the music.

items.summary: Gulf leaders have rallied in solidarity with Qatar as global condemnation over the strikes grows.

items.summary: A senior Pacific minister has warned Australia's energy transition is no longer defensible, following a landmark legal ruling.

items.title: 'Not what we wanted': Australian-Nepalis speak out amid Nepal's violent gen Z protests
items.summary: Pride, frustration, fear. For some members of Australia's Nepali diaspora, Nepal's worst unrest in decades has brought mixed emotions.

items.summary: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price has been dumped from the coalition frontbench after refusing to apologise for comments about Indian migrants.

items.title: How much you need for a comfortable retirement? | NAB latest to cut jobs
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Marcus Bogdan from Blackmore Capital about the day's market action including why banks seem to be on a job cutting cycle, plus Stephnie Youssef speaks with ASFA CEO Mary Delahunty to find out how much money is needed in super to fund a comfortable retirement.

items.title: Climate Change and China's Charm: Australia's pressing role to play in the Pacific
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is in the Solomon Islands for the region's most important annual political meeting. With climate change and regional security at the forefront of discussions, Australia will work to solidify its role as a reliable partner and counter to China's growing security presence in the Pacific.

items.title: Breakthrough chlamydia vaccine offers hope for endangered koalas
items.summary: A world-first vaccine for chlamydia in koala populations developed over more than a decade may help the fight against the disease.

items.title: Israel's strike in Qatar a 'devastating blow' to Gaza ceasefire negotiations, experts say
items.summary: Israel has carried out airstrikes and other military action in Lebanon, Syria, Iran and Yemen in the course of the Gaza conflict, but experts say its latest attack on Qatar marks a significant departure and "upsets" efforts for peace.

items.summary: Poland invoked NATO's Article 4 for urgent talks after Russian drones violated the country's airspace.

items.title: Australian-Nepalis dismayed and distressed at protests and violence in Nepal
items.summary: Nepal's Prime Minister has resigned amid anti-government protests, as demonstrators set fire to Parliament and the homes of some of the country's top political leaders. It comes as a "Gen Z" protest movement was triggered by a ban on social media, which has now been overturned. Concerns have been raised by the Nepali community in Australia, calling for peace in the country.

items.title: Will Israel's attack on Hamas officials in Qatar derail peace talks?
items.summary: Israel has struck the Qatari capital of Doha, killing five Hamas members and one Qatari security official. It has led to an outcry from Qatar, Washington, and humanitarian groups, with concern the strike will jeopardise fragile ceasefire talks.

items.title: 'The wrong thing to do': Australia, and the world, react to Israel’s strike on Hamas in Qatar
items.summary: Qatar has once again been caught in the crossfire of Middle East turmoil, with world leaders condemning the attacks amid concerns they deal a serious blow to ceasefire efforts.

items.title: 'The wrong thing to do': Australia, and the world, react to Israel’s strike on Hamas in Qatar

items.title: Lifting caps from first home buyer scheme will help some but fuel wider price rise
items.summary: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

items.title: Lifting caps from first home buyer scheme will help some but fuel wider price rise

items.summary: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

items.title: 'Hiding these results does not make the problem go away': Doctors lash NSW Health data
items.summary: The Australian Medical Association NSW president has said stark figures were buried in the Bureau of Health Information's new report and questioned the presentation of data. The bureau has said it applies the same criteria of "objectivity, fairness and meaningfulness" in every report.

items.title: Qatar condemns Israeli attacks on Hamas leaders as 'cowardly' violation of international law
items.summary: Israel's airstrike on Hamas leaders in Qatar killed five, including a commander's son, prompting Qatari condemnation and US unease over ceasefire efforts.

items.title: A car bomb exploded outside my work. Three decades on, thunder still scares me
items.summary: On 27 March 1986, Debra Richardson was at her desk at Russell Street Police Headquarters in Melbourne when a car bomb detonated on the street outside. The former senior constable says the explosion, that killed fellow officer Angela Rose Taylor, changed her life forever.

items.title: The simple shopping swap that could save you $4,000 a year
items.summary: A comparison group examined the cost of 20 staple items at two major supermarkets. Here's what it found.

items.title: Palestinians flee Gaza City as Israel airdrops leaflets ordering them to leave
items.summary: Israel has warned it will launch a full-scale assault on Gaza City.

items.title: Gaza aid flotilla reports second attack after Tunisian authorities say 'no drones' involved in first
items.summary: The vessel was off the coast of Tunisia when it was struck by a drone, organisers of the Global Sumud Flotilla allege. Tunisian authorities have rejected the claim, saying the explosion originated inside the boat.

items.title: Gaza aid flotilla reports second attack after Tunisian authorities say 'no drones' involved in first
items.summary: The vessel was off the coast of Tunisia when it was struck by a drone, organisers of the Global Sumud Flotilla allege. Tunisian authorities have rejected the claim, saying the explosion originated inside the boat.

items.title: Albanese in the Pacific: Australia's struggle for influence — and a key hope
items.summary: This year's Pacific Islands Forum has become a flashpoint in a broader tussle for influence between China and Australia and China and Taiwan — and is also likely to see Australia firming up its bid to co-host a major climate conference with the Pacific in 2026.

items.title: ANZ slashes 3,500 jobs, are there more to come?
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a closer look at ANZ's decision to cut 3,500 employees and 1,000 contractors and what it means for the sector with Nathan Zaia from Morningstar and Damien Boey from Wilson Asset Management.

items.title: Australia's security deal with Vanuatu delayed
items.summary: A major security agreement with Vanuatu has been delayed ahead of the Pacific Islands Forum in the Solomon Islands. Amid concerns over the impacts on Vanuatu's regional partnerships and infrastructure investment, Vanuatu says the $500 million deal with Australia needs further consideration.

items.title: French political fiasco as Macron faces finding fifth new PM in 24 months
items.summary: France is facing a new political crisis after the country's parliament voted to oust its Prime Minister, François Bayrou. It comes as part of the opposition party's plan to bring down the government in the face of increasing national debt, and a deepening political crisis.

items.title: Banksy mural at Royal Courts of Justice swiftly covered after appearing overnight
items.summary: The new Banksy mural appeared to be a commentary on the arrest of hundreds of demonstrators in London for their support of proscribed terrorist organisation Palestine Action.

items.title: Six killed, 20 injured in gun attack on East Jerusalem bus stop
items.summary: Six civilians were killed and 20 injured when two Palestinian gunmen opened fire at Jerusalem’s Ramot Junction bus stop, sending commuters running in terror. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed Israel would retaliate, linking the assault to Israel’s ongoing war in Gaza, where airstrikes have destroyed dozens of high-rise buildings and a ground invasion is imminent.

items.title: Liberal MP Julian Leeser apologises for Jacinta Price's comments on Indian migration
items.summary: Liberal frontbencher Julian Leeser has apologised to the Indian community in his electorate for comments made by Jacinta Nampijinpa Price, as calls grow for Price to apologise for the "hurt that has been caused".

items.title: Logging halted to create a koala retreat
items.summary: Australia will halt logging in a large stretch of woodland on the east coast to create a retreat for koalas, in an attempt to save the local population from extinction. The announcement, which will impact six timber mills and hundreds of workers, has caused outrage in the forestry industry. New South Wales Premier Chris Minns says the decision wasn't taken lightly and those affected will be supported.

items.title: French parliament ousts prime minister, deepening political crisis for Macron
items.summary: President Emmanuel Macron will now hunt for his fifth prime minister in less than two years.

items.title: The new regional hotspot that's seen a 1,500 per cent surge of city folk

items.title: Weak US data spurs rate cut chance, and the supermarkets court case

items.title: 'I thought I was gone': Calls for greater awareness of prostate cancer
items.summary: September is Prostate Cancer Awareness month, with the disease now the most common cause of death from cancer for men in Australia. Advocacy groups are pushing for greater awareness and regular testing for all men in the country, including those from a multicultural background.

items.title: 'Loved by everyone': Shark attack victim remembered as community 'keystone'

items.summary: Opposition leader Sussan Ley says senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's comments about Labor favouring Indian migrants shouldn't have been made.

items.title: Radiotherapy could save your life: dispelling the misconceptions
items.summary: Despite being a proven life-saving treatment, 1 in 5 Australians who need radiotherapy never receive it. This year, on September 7, the first-ever World Radiotherapy Awareness Day will be launched, and experts say it's an opportunity to dispel fears of the treatment.

items.title: Australian women are living longer but it's not all good news
items.summary: The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has produced a snap shot of Women’s health across the life course. While rates of cancer have gone down for women over the last 25 years, younger women continue to experience higher rates of depression and other mental health conditions.

items.title: Hope and hate: how governments around the world are responding to 'illegal' immigration
items.summary: Recently, local news headlines have been dominated by stories about anti-immigration rallies which were held across Australia on the last day of August. But it's not just in Australia where migration has created such deep feelings - it's also an issue that has been front and centre in the US as Donald Trump fulfils his election campaign promise to carry out mass deportations. There are now at least a million fewer immigrants in the US, raising questions about the impact of their absence on key industries like agriculture and construction. Migration is also a major concern in Europe, which has long grappled with what to do with the scores of people fleeing war and poverty in their home countries. This episode of the TOO HARD BASKET focuses on these complexities.

items.title: Calls for justice after two boys stabbed to death in 'heinous' Melbourne attack
items.summary: Two boys have been killed in western Melbourne in what police suspect is a series of targeted attacks.

items.title: An Australian couple bought a French palace for $1.2m. Strangers are helping pay to restore it
items.summary: Palatial French estates are being snapped up by overseas buyers for less than a median-priced home in Sydney. But the initial outlay is usually just the start of long and expensive restoration journey. One Australian couple is funding their project in unique ways.

items.title: Melanie was sceptical of this underutilised cancer treatment. It saved her life
items.summary: One in five eligible Australian cancer patients never receives this form of treatment, according to research cited by Australian oncologists.

items.title: Beaches closed after fatal shark attack on Sydney's Northern Beaches
items.summary: Drones are being used to monitor shark activity, after a fatality on Sydney's Northern Beaches.

items.title: A surfer's death in Sydney could stir up the shark net debate. So why are they so controversial?
items.summary: A fatal shark attack on Sydney's Northern Beaches has come amid debates about the efficacy and environmental effects of shark nets. So do they actually protect swimmers, and what are the alternatives?

items.title: Dee Why shark attack: Northern Beaches man mauled to death in 'terrible tragedy'
items.summary: Beaches from Manly to Narrabeen are likely to remain closed for at least 24 hours after a man was fatally attacked by a shark at Dee Why.

items.title: Loveness says she experienced racism while working as a nurse. She isn't the only one
items.summary: A new report has shed light on the experiences of racism nurses and midwives from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds face at work.

items.title: Israeli military urges Gaza City residents to leave after destroying high-rise tower
items.summary: The Israeli military continues to carry out heavy strikes on Gaza City, as Hamas releases a new video of hostages seized on October 7.

items.title: How a grandmother's curry tells the story of a family's migration journey
items.summary: Making a chicken curry on stage is not what you would usually expect when visiting the theatre. But for actor Joshua Jamil Hinton, it's the centrepiece of his show, due to open in Brisbane this month, telling his story of living between different cultures and grappling with his own identity.

items.title: Anti-immigration rallies ignore Australia's economic dependence on migration
items.summary: Australia in anti-immigration marches.At the heart of what organisers called the 'March for Australia' rallies was a call to end "mass migration", which protesters claimed is to blame for issues like the housing crisis and rise in cost of living. Experts say a paradox exists in the anti-immigration ideas put forward at these rallies: the very people protesters want fewer of are the ones propping up the nation's economy, workforce, and future.

items.title: In Sydney's 'Little India', locals say Price is 'way off' with her Indian migrant remarks
items.summary: Several locals in Sydney's 'Little India' say the senator's remarks unfairly target their community.

items.title: Gob has been making rafts in his local river his whole life. It's never made him sick until now
items.summary: Several major rivers flowing across the border from Myanmar to Thailand have been contaminated with dangerously high levels of arsenic, threatening to cause a public health crisis.

items.title: Gob has been making rafts in his local river his whole life. It's never made him sick until now
items.summary: Several major rivers flowing across the border from Myanmar to Thailand have been contaminated with dangerously high levels of arsenic, threatening to cause a public health crisis.

items.title: ARIA chart changes to bring diversity of artists - and is the RBA done with cutting interest rates?
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with ARIA CEO Annabelle Herd about the changes to the ARIA Charts will highlight diverse artists in the industry, Madeline Dunk from ANZ explains why she thinks the RBA may be done cutting interest rates, and Bryce Anderson from Morningstar goes through the day's sharemarket action.

items.title: Taxpayer hit or investment? Australia's 2035 emissions target raises $500bn question
items.summary: As the government is set to announce Australia's 2035 emissions goal, the Business Council of Australia warns an ambitious goal could carry a $500 billion price tag. The Coalition says the figure represents a warning of soaring costs but others say it's an investment opportunity.

items.title: Aftershocks hit Afghanistan after more than 2,200 people die in earthquakes
items.summary: Two aftershocks have struck Afghanistan in the space of 12 hours, after a series of quakes that have devastated parts of the country.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 5 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Albanese hails 'constructive' talk with Trump amid calls for in-person meeting
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and US President Donald Trump have spoken for the fourth time to discuss trade, security and critical minerals.

items.title: Are neo-Nazis REALLY gaining traction in Australia?
items.summary: What was sold as a rally against mass immigration had far right ideology from the start. With neo-Nazis attending the rally and attempting to recruit new members, is far-right extremism on the rise in Australia? Dr Callum Jones and Professor Greg Barton break down what's behind these rallies, and how the government should respond.

items.title: A blood moon will soon be visible across Australia. Here's everything you need to know
items.summary: This will be the final chance for Australians to see the blood moon in 2025.

items.title: The paradox at the heart of calls to end 'mass migration' in Australia
items.summary: Community leaders say Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price’s comments are fuelling division, as experts warn migrants are being unfairly blamed for housing and cost of living pressures.

items.title: Call for action after report details racism faced by nurses, midwives
items.summary: A new report from the New South Wales Nurses and Midwives Association has revealed the alarming rates of racism and discrimination experienced by Aboriginal and culturally diverse healthcare workers. The union has called for action to address the issue, with nearly 70 percent of survey respondents saying they face racism at work.

items.title: Xi’s 'new world order', Indonesia unrest & Thailand’s political plight
items.summary: In this episode: China’s military parade and its guests of honour the US media has dubbed ‘the Axis of Upheaval’, protesters mobilise across Indonesia as parliamentary allowances trigger mass unrest. Plus, Thailand faces yet another political crisis while environmental concerns escalate across the border in Myanmar. And the holographic warning to all would-be criminals.

items.title: Is Victoria Australia's crime state and what does it mean for insurance premiums?
items.summary: Car theft claims rose to a record $233m in Victoria last financial year, but fell in every other state so Stephanie Youssef speaks with Insuance Council of Australia CEO Andrew Hall to find out what can be done about it and what it means for premiums, plus SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a closer look at the sharemarket with Ben Clark from TMS Private.

items.title: After Australia's economic surprise, here's what could happen to your mortgage
items.summary: Public holidays and the latest release of a video game console were all important elements in Australia's recent GDP growth, something that might mean there may not be many interest rate cuts left to come.

items.title: Liberals distance themselves from Price's Indian migrant remark as backlash grows
items.summary: The Northern Territory senator falsely claimed Labor was prioritising Indian migrants to bolster its vote. She walked back the remarks, but later said she did not believe she had anything to apologise for.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 4 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: 20,000 more aged care packages more quickly after Labor agrees to Coalition deal
items.summary: 20,000 more home care packages are to be available to vulnerable older Australians after the federal government was forced to make a deal with the Coalition. It was the first major test faced by Labor since it was re-elected, which was cornered in the senate to make changes to its aged care reform policy.

items.title: Charges laid, but Camp Sovereignty on 'high alert' amid fears of another attack
items.summary: At Melbourne's Camp Sovereignty, there's grief and anger. But there's also resilience.

items.title: This jailed Australian needs help. But a major move has put them in a 'horror situation'
items.summary: Experts warn the Australian government’s decision to expel Iran’s ambassador and designate the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps a terrorist organisation could throw a ‘spanner in the works’ for an Australian citizen detained in Iran.

items.title: ASX 200’s worst day since April; Australian economy grows faster than expected
items.summary: The Australian sharemarket has experienced its worst single-day drop since April, with all 11 sectors finishing in the red. For more, Rena Sarumpaet spoke with Perpetual’s Head of Investment Strategy, Matt Sherwood. Plus, Australia’s GDP expanded by a larger-than-expected 0.6% in the June quarter. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves spoke with NAB Chief Economist Sally Auld about what that means for the economy.

items.title: Revealed: Alone Australia's toughest location yet as show set for return
items.summary: Subzero temperatures, deep snows, frozen lakes and icy forests await the latest participants of Alone Australia.

items.title: Simon's $500 gift card purchase led to an 'astonishing' discovery
items.summary: Simon Dean was puzzled when he bought a $500 gift card only to find it had already been redeemed. When he decided to investigate what could have happened, what he found astonished him.

items.title: Second Afghan quake brings more trauma to the shattered region
items.summary: Thousands of people living in Afghanistan's mountainous Nangarhar province have been left bereaved, homeless and traumatised after Sunday's earthquake. Then, amid ongoing and petrifying tremors, another earthquake came.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 3 Sep 2025
items.summary: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: 'Overwhelmed with fear': Entire village wiped out, hundreds dead in Sudan landslide
items.summary: A Sudanese rebel group has appealed for international aid after a landslide buried Tarseen village in Darfur, killing up to 1,000 people and leaving only one survivor.

items.title: Illegal mining is costing Thailand's forests, rivers, lands and future dearly
items.summary: Local communities say an environmental crisis is unfolding along the Thai-Myanmar border, where dangerously high levels of arsenic have been detected in several major rivers. There is now growing evidence a surge in unregulated rare earth mining in Myanmar's southern Shan State is to blame. And now, with the contamination reaching the Mekong River, environmentalists say the effects could be felt right through Southeast Asia.

items.title: Wanted: Essential workers in regional Australia
items.summary: Many regional towns across Australia struggle to attract essential workers - like doctors, teachers and aged-care staff – often due to lack of affordable housing and other factors. While similar equivalents exist in other states and territories, an initiative across regional areas in New South Wales is hoping to change this by offering essential workers support to find housing, schools and community groups to make them feel welcome and connected.

items.title: COVID-19 travel credits: How to check if you have them, and when do they expire?
items.summary: Travel credits held with one of the airlines also have an expiry date.

items.title: I'm an Australian and wanted nothing to do with religion. Here's what changed my mind
items.summary: While latest Census data pointed to a significant downward trend in Australians identifying as Christian, there was an uptick in religious diversity. Some research suggests 38 per cent of gen Z identify as spiritual and there is an increase of gen Z men turning to religion.

items.title: Gold and silver prices hit milestones & ASX hit by ex-dividend stocks
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves speaks with Josh Gilbert from eToro to find out why gold prices hit a new record while silver reached a 14 year high, plus why the ASX fell as a number of companies traded ex-dividend.

items.title: Australia's greatest threat: Not war, not terror, not pandemic... but the climate
items.summary: As the Coalition remains divided over net zero emission targets, former security leaders are warning the government that climate change poses an immediate national security threat.In the Senate, the Greens are pushing for the release of the National Climate Risk Assessment Report while Nationals Senator Matt Canavan is pushing ahead with a bill to repeal net zero.

items.title: Racism in the health sector can kill, research shows. What can be done to save lives?
items.summary: Racism is a "critical issue" in health, which can lead to a breakdown in trust between patients and healthcare workers.

items.title: Spain prepares for future extreme weather after 'environmental catastrophe'
items.summary: After a summer in which much of western and southern Europe were impacted by catastrophic fires and searing heat, Spain now forming a plan to prepare for future disasters.Scientists say action is needed to reduce emissions and increase resilience, in the face of inevitable worsening conditions.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 2 Sep 2025
items.summary: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: No end in sight: famine tightens its grip on Gaza as Israeli families mourn hostages
items.summary: Hungry Palestinians have queued at a soup kitchen in Khan Younis, empty pots in hand, as famine tightens its grip on Gaza. Families say aid is failing to reach them, while shortages and soaring prices have left markets bare. The United Nations says nearly half a million people in Gaza face catastrophic hunger, nearly a quarter of the territory's population.

items.title: Cap on Australia's migration numbers to stay the same, government confirms
items.summary: The government said it has undertaken consultations with the states and territories, which recommended maintaining the size and composition of the migration program.

items.title: How Australia's social media ban could make life 'a lot more difficult' for those most at risk
items.summary: Online anonymity is often a lifeline for those "most at risk" in the community. Experts say the government's proposed social media ban could cut off vulnerable people from critical digital spaces.

items.title: Aboriginal Camp Sovereignty site attacked by anti-immigration protesters
items.summary: An Aboriginal gathering place and burial ground was attacked in Melbourne on Sunday by participants in the city's anti-immigration rallies. Police are investigating the incident, which witnesses say involved self-proclaimed neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell and up to 100 others. The incident has been condemned by political leaders, with Senator Lidia Thorpe calling for a federal inquiry.

items.title: Spring season property hotspots & reporting season fallout
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves speaks with Tim Lawless from Cotality Australia about the direction for home prices as the Spring selling season begins and to find out where the property hotspots are, plus Mathan Somasundaram from Deep Data Analytics takes a look back at the reporting season that was and looks ahead at what to expect now.

items.title: 'Wake-up call': Government urged to address rise in far-right extremism after racist rallies
items.summary: Politicians have condemned the racism and xenophobia displayed at various anti-immigration protests over the weekend. After violent clashes and a large neo-Nazi presence, the Greens are calling on the government to urgently address rising right-wing extremism in Australia.

items.title: Protesters claim high migration levels have 'torn' Australia. Here's what experts say
items.summary: Australia's migration numbers and policies were the target of March for Australia's anti-immigration rallies over the weekend. Here's what experts have to say about their claims.

items.title: Thousands rally against immigration with neo-Nazis taking the spotlight
items.summary: A wave of nation-wide anti-immigration rallies have swept Australia's capital cities, with thousands joining marches and clashing with police and counter-protesters across the country. Organisers say the events were calling for an end to what they consider "mass migration" into Australia, while neo-Nazi groups infiltrated a number of the events to stir up chaos.

items.title: US makes plans for post-war Gaza, while flotilla aims to break Israel's blockade
items.summary: A post-war plan for Gaza is circulating within the US government. Meanwhile, Israel's Defence Minister says its forces have killed a Hamas spokesman in a strike on Gaza.And a flotilla of 20 boats has set sail from Barcelona for Gaza, in hopes of getting past Israel’s blockade.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 1 Sep 2025
items.summary: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Hundreds of former detainees to be deported to Nauru set to live among community
items.summary: A government source has told SBS News around 280 non-citizens formerly in Australian immigration detention could be sent to Nauru to live among the community.

items.title: 'An attack on multiculturalism': government's new Nauru deal greeted with alarm
items.summary: The Federal Government has struck a $400 million deal with Nauru that it says paves the way for deportation of the so-called NZYQ cohort. The announcement has been met with outrage from advocates, human rights lawyers, and the Greens. Critics say the deal threatens fundamental legal rights in ways that could be applied more broadly.

items.title: 'Like the Castle': The Australian families who could lose farms in Trump's rare earths push
items.summary: In north-west Victoria, a David and Goliath battle is playing out between farmers and the rare earths mining industry which has been backed by state and federal governments as the world scrambles to extract key minerals.

items.title: Sydney Marathon 2025: Records broken as Sifan Hassan, Hailemaryam Kiros win
items.summary: Dutch superstar Sifan Hassan and Ethiopia's Hailemaryam Kiros have triumphed in the Sydney marathon as Kenyan legend Eliud Kipchoge battled to ninth.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Cricketer Usman Khawaja on why he is calling on sporting bodies to consider banning Israel
items.summary: Usman Khawaja says he raised the issue of imposing sanctions on Israel over its actions in Gaza during his meeting with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.

items.title: Scottish brothers reach Cairns after record-breaking row across the Pacific Ocean
items.summary: After more than four months at sea, the brothers reunited with loved ones — along with pizza and beer — as they reached their final destination.

items.title: Scottish brothers reach Cairns after record-breaking row across the Pacific Ocean
items.summary: After more than four months at sea, the brothers reunited with loved ones — along with pizza and beer — as they reached their final destination.

items.title: Is your family sitting on a goldmine - and are you willing to sell it?
items.summary: Some cultures value gold jewellery above all when it comes to gifts for special events such as weddings or birthdays. But with the price up around 70 per cent in the last five years, more people are torn between whether to sell these items to make ends meet or keep them for sentimental reasons.

items.title: Khawaja's proposed Israel sports ban would violate 'equal rights', Olympic body says
items.summary: Australia's opening batsman Usman Khawaja has argued international sporting bodies should consider removing Israel, over its treatment of Palestinians in Gaza.

items.title: Why Anthony Albanese was chased by angry farmers on tractors
items.summary: Protesters at the annual Bush Summit event also used tractors and fire engines to block Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan from leaving.

items.title: Iran ambassador expelled, Trump’s military crackdown & KPop Demon Hunters
items.summary: In this episode: Australia punishes Iran after dramatic revelations in Canberra, Trump’s latest threats to set troops on more Democrat-held cities in the US, and a mass deportation pitch from the UK’s far right. Plus, why Venezuelan housewives are joining Maduro’s militia and South Korea’s supernatural export pops on global streaming.

items.title: 'It creates a worry in your head': International students plan to stay home during protests
items.summary: International education is Australia's fourth largest export, but with protests looming that demand dramatic cuts to migration, some experts think the event could "cast a shadow over the brand of Australia".

items.title: Accused cop killer Dezi Freeman is still on the run. Here's what we know about him
items.summary: The suspect behind the Porepunkah police shooting is still at large in the Victorian high country. Here's what we know about accused cop killer Dezi Freeman.

items.title: Two arrested, released in search for fugitive alleged killer | Midday News Bulletin 29 August 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, two people arrested as search continues for a suspected police killer in regional Victoria, police charge a man with the murder of a Western Sydney mother, in a crime with alleged gang links. And in tennis, Jannik Sinner topples Alexei Popyrin to enter round three of the US Open.

items.title: Knights of the (productivity) roundtable ft. Senator Jacqui Lambie
items.summary: A lot has happened since the last sitting week. The Prime Minister announced Australia's plan to soon recognise Palestinian statehood, and the best economic minds gathered to solve the productivity crisis. We break down why you should care about productivity at all, and Jacqui Lambie talks through her idea for a 'climate army'.

items.title: CEO Series: Wesfarmers Rob Scott calls for action on Victorian retail crime
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Wesfarmers CEO Rob Scott about the company's $2.9bn profit, bonus shareholder returns and the economic environment, plus a look at the day on the sharemarket including Qantas' second best profit result ever, with Angus Geddes from Fat Prophets.

items.title: 'Incredibly alarming': Albanese's proposed rules for deporting non-citizens criticised
items.summary: Human rights lawyers are concerned about a new government proposal designed to remove legal obstacles to resettling three people in Nauru who were released as a result of the landmark "NZYQ" High Court decision.

items.title: Two dead in another US school shooting
items.summary: Two children have been killed and 17 people wounded in a Catholic school shooting in Minneapolis in the United States. Authorities say they're investigating the shooting as an act of domestic terrorism and a hate crime targeting Catholics.

items.title: FBI investigating Minneapolis school shooting as 'hate crime targeting Catholics'
items.summary: The FBI is investigating the shooting as an act of terrorism and an anti-Catholic hate crime.

items.title: FBI investigating Minneapolis school shooting as 'hate crime targeting Catholics'
items.summary: The FBI is investigating the shooting as an act of terrorism and an anti-Catholic hate crime.

items.title: 'Strong and comfortable': Mitch Brown becomes first AFL player to come out as bisexual
items.summary: Mitch Brown, the first AFL player to publicly identify as bisexual, has spoken about the fear of having his sexuality discovered while he was playing.

items.title: CEO Series: Flight Centre's Graham Turner on airfares, AI and flights to the US
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Flight Centre CEO Graham Turner following the group's results announcement to find out more about the operating environment, airfares and consumer trends, plus Michael Wayne from Medallion Financial Group goes through the day's sharemarket action including a look at the surprise rise in inflation.

items.title: Australia - allergy capital of the world
items.summary: The number of Australians living with allergy has doubled in nearly 20 years, according to a new report, which examines the financial and personal costs of the chronic condition. Demand for services is unprecedented, and experts warn allergy does not just impact health - it can reshape sufferers’ lives.

items.title: CEO Series: Coles' Leah Weckert, Fortescue's Dino Otranto & Tyro's Jon Davey
items.summary: In this special extended edition of SBS On the Money, join SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves as he speaks with Coles Group CEO Leah Weckert to find out how shoppers are feeling, Fortescue CEO Dino Otranto on how the political landscape is impacting his operations while Stephanie Youssef discusses Tyro's results with CEO Jon Davey, plus hear from Jamie Hannah from VanEck on the day on the sharemarket.
